review: McKay simplifies a highly complicated subject (economy) with all types of ingenious (and hilarious) narrative devices (even breaking the fourth wall many times) to bring us an intelligent story about those who decided to bet against the American economy and the revolting dishonesty of a lot of people involved in it.

Better known for his comedy films like Anchorman, Step Brothers and Talladega Nights, The Big Short is a big leap for director Adam McKay. Going from improvised Will Ferrell gags to dealing with the true story of the global financial crisis of 2008 is quite a departure from his usual comfort zone. If truth be told, I'm not a fan of his comedies and had some strong reservations about this but it was hard to resist seeing such quality actors sink their teeth into a very personal subject that has affected us all. Hedge fund managers Michael Burry (Christian Bale) and Mark Baum (Steve Carell), trader Jared Vennett (Ryan Gosling) and retired banker Ben Rickert (Brad Pitt) all work within the financial sector. However, they see a problem arising; the housing credit market is about to collapse and no-one but them can see it coming. They see it as a perfect time to invest against the banks and make money from what turns out to be the fall of the global economy.First off, The Big Short is not an easy film to like. It's so dialogue laden that the bankers and brokers jargon can leave you scratching your head in bewilderment. There's really only so much talk of C.D.O's, Short's and Subprime's that a person can take but that's exactly the point. McKay knows this and he's clever enough to point out that the bankers want it this way. They want the ordinary, every-day working stiff to think it's only them that know how to manage our money for us. McKay doesn't pull any punches and goes straight for the jugular when it's comes to the inner dealings of these immoral and reckless financial swindlers who brought down the world economy. He depicts their carefree avarice in such a detestable way that you're left infuriated. If this was his intention (which I'm sure it was) then you have to say that his film is a success. However, the manner in which he does it can be off-putting. There's a kinetic energy to McKay's direction and, although impressive, it's a little messy with too many jump cuts and forth-wall-breaking moments. Despite his best efforts, his stylistic devices don't always help you to understand the complexity of these events and he finds it tricky to fully transcend the confusion by employing a frantic pace to everything. That said, this is a hugely difficult subject to tackle and he does deserve some credit for managing any form of coherence at all. McKay is clearly angry and it's an anger I, wholeheartedly, share. His scathing attack on the fraudulent activities of these people is potent. His message (and conscience) is clear and his attempt to bring it to a mainstream audience, with quality actors in tow, is an admirable one. It's a good ensemble he's put together and they all deliver fine work; Pitt is the one who takes a back seat and seems underused but Carell proves that his dramatic chops from Foxcatcher was no fluke while Bale has some fun with his eccentric glass-eyed turn. From the leads, I found Gosling to be the most comfortable with his cocksure wolfishness and it's always a pleasure to have the likes of Melissa Leo and Marisa Tomei make an (all-be-it brief) appearance. I can only hope that with such a recognisable cast that the masses wake from their slumber and pay attention to, not so much the disjointed film itself, but the message and teaching behind it.It's not an entirely successful endeavour as it struggles to entertain without getting bogged down in investment lingo but it's an important morality tale with a message that still resonates. If Joy is this year's film to embrace the capitalist system then The Big Short is the indictment of it.Mark Walker

Adam McKay does a great job taking a convoluted subject and turning it into a very comprehensible film. All actors do a great job, especially Bale, Carell and Gosling, and the directing is unique with it's cutaways. This film is both funny and fascinating, and while I realize a lot of it is compressed, dramatized, the fact that this is all true (by Hollywood standards, but still this happened to some degree) is stunning.

I was honestly expecting more--much more. All the pieces of a great film were there--great cast, important story--but The Big Short fails to do any of these elements justice due to some questionable directorial and editing choices made by McKay and a striking lack of depth. I commend the film, however, for providing a digestible perspective on the 2008 crisis and another venue for Bale and Carrell to show off their acting skills.

Adam McKay is not exactly the kind of name you associate with a prestige picture that's building serious Oscar heat. McKay is best known as the director and co-writer of Will Ferrell's best movies, from Anchorman and its sequel to Talladega Nights and the underrated 2010 buddy cop movie, The Other Guys. If you stuck through the closing credits for Guys, you were treated to an animated education lesson on the size of Wall street's greed and accountability in regards to the 2008 financial crisis. It was impassioned, angry, and an interesting note to end an otherwise goofy comedy. The Big Short is based upon Michael Lewis' (Moneyball) best-selling book and it's a disaster movie where the biggest disaster is the world economy. The movie McKay co-adapted and directed is bristling with intelligence, indignation, and a clear purpose. He wants to make you very angry, and by the end if you're not, you haven't been paying enough attention.In the wake of the financial collapse in 2008, the fallout was so tremendous that many people felt nobody could have seen this coming. There were a few and they made out like bandits while trying to warn others about the impending doom. In the early 2000s, Michael Burry (Christian Bale) is a hedgefund manager who sees warning signs that the housing market is a bubble ready to burst. He sees the toxicity of the majority sub-prime mortgages wrapped together and sold as a seemingly safe security, a CDO (collateralized debt obligation). His bosses think he's mad and they're furious when they discover Burry has gone from bank to bank making big bets against the housing market. The banks are eager to take what they believe to be easy money from a sucker. How could the housing market burst? Other Wall Street investors take notice of Burry, notably Jared Vennett (Ryan Gosling) who pitches the plan to "short" the housing market. Nobody takes him seriously except Mark Baum (Steve Carell) and his small team who works for Goldman Sachs. Baum is curious how something so large could go unnoticed, so he and his team fly to Florida and Vegas to investigate the realities of the market and what they find does not match the rosy cheerleading from Wall Street. A pair of wannabe traders (Finn Witrock, John Magaro) stumbles across Burry's analysis and try to make their own bets, except they need a bigger name to make the trades. They reach out to an ex-Wall Street trader (Brad Pitt) who agrees to shepherd them on this quixotic quest. Are these men righteous defenders of fraud or just people trying to get their own cut of the pie?The brilliance of The Big Short lies in its accessibility and the virulent passion that McKay has for the subject matter. The movie is structured like a heist and an underdog story, suckering in the audience to root for the upstarts trying to fleece the big banks and profit off their greed and stupidity. For the first 90 minutes or so, the film comes across like a caper and we follow our group of misfits as they fight against the conventional wisdom that the housing market could never topple. These guys see the signs and the risks that others could not or would not see, especially since the flow of money was rich and the good times could be shared, which lead to collusion from the very same agencies designed to regulate and enforce the financial laws. For those 90 minutes the movie flies by on its sense of whimsy and are-we-getting-away-with-this good fortune, putting our band of misfits in position to win big on the losses of the ignorant and fraudulent. And then, in one swift move, it all comes down and you're reminded, rather indignantly by Pitt's character, that what they are benefiting from is the meltdown of the U.S. housing market and by extension the American economy. What once felt like a celebratory caper now starts to feel queasy, and it's in the last act that The Big Short reminds you just how awful the events of the 2008 financial crisis were and how these guys did nothing more than benefit from mass misery. These are not heroes, though Mark Baum is given plenty of moral grandstanding moments that present him as the closest thing we have in the picture. These were a bunch of guys who got rich betting on a lot of other people's bad bets, bets that almost destroyed the world's economic systems. The concluding half hour feels like a sudden stop after a sugar rush, where you're left to question your decision-making but also come to terms with the reality of what seemed like a fun time. McKay lures his audience in with the guise of a heist/underdog story, appealing and accessible avenues of cinema, and then serves the cod hard medicine in the concluding moments.McKay is admirably trying to educate and advocate while he entertains, but he truly wants the audience to understand why they should be sharpening their pitchforks. At several points, characters will break the fourth wall and talk directly into the camera, admitting that certain events didn't happen exactly as we saw, or occasionally they'll remind us that what we watched was exactly how it happened. It's a measure that isn't overplayed and helps juice the spirits of the movie, becoming something of a confidant in the schemes with the onscreen participants. When things gets a little hard to understand with the mountain of Wall Street lingo, McKay will cut to celebrity cameos to help explain the more arcane instruments of the financial system. Margot Robbie luxuriates in a bubble bath and explains sub-prime mortgages, Anthony Bourdain explains CDOs, and Selena Gomez, in a rather cogent analogy, explains synthetic CDOs as an endless chain of side bets being made off one hand of blackjack. The movie goes pretty fast and a viewer might experience information overload, but McKay knows when to slow things down and provide a well-timed assist, so that his learned audience will see the true extent of the corruption and greed rampant in how Wall Street handled its business.Of the three storylines, I found Mark Baum and his team easily the most interesting and I think McKay and co-screenwriter Charles Randolph (The Interpreter) agreed, which is why he's the biggest part of the movie. Burry gets things started but he recedes into the background after the first act, and that's where Baum and his financial team step into the spotlight to further explore how unstable the housing market just might be. I think this is Carell's best dramatic performance to date (I wasn't wowed by Foxcatcher). He's playing perhaps one of the angriest people seen on screen but that's because he has a moral center and the bad business practices, let alone the sociopathic greed of his "peers," constantly enrage him. He's something like a flabbergasted crusading journalist who keeps shaking his head in stupefying revulsion at just how deep this whole thing goes. Having Baum as our entry into the moral morass of Wall Street allows the audience to feel a sense of ethical superiority, and then like Pitt's character, it can all go away with one perfectly articulated retort. There's a moment where Baum is lambasting a mortgage ratings officer (Melissa Leo, her only scene too) after she admits that if they don't rate bad mortgages as good, the banks will just go to their competitor, and then she accuses Baum of being a hypocrite. His reason for the office visit is not that his outrage at the fraud but the fact that this fraud is holding up his winnings. He's not the crusader he may wish to be. Bale (American Hustle) and Gosling (Only God Forgives) are perfectly cast and provide strong supporting work in small doses spread throughout. There is a bevy of familiar faces (Marisa Tomei, Rafe Spall, Max Greenfield, Karen Gillan) appearing in small moments as if everybody in Hollywood wanted to get in on McKay's party.There is one annoying misstep in the movie and it occurs about halfway and it's made to stretch out the stakes in a haphazard manner. The Big Short is a disaster movie where the audience knows exactly when the disaster is coming, and yet there's a section in the middle where the characters are all left in doubt whether their big bets will pay off because of the ratings fraud. Burry is threatened with losing his job. It's silly because we know the economy is going to crash in 2008, but the movie throws out a weak obstacle that, hey, maybe it won't crash. It reminds me of the Hinderberg movie from the 1970s. There were several moments where it looked like that zeppelin full of hydrogen was going to go up in fames... except students of history know that moment is fated in New Jersey, so all the close calls were foolish fake-outs for a major event that was well anticipated. We all know the economy is going down so there's no need for the manufactured doubts.McKay and company want to wake up a fairly apathetic general public about the crimes and negligence of the Wall Street robber barons that risked the world's economy and then managed to skip out on the tab. The tones can juggle wildly, and I'd credit McKay's background in comedy for his ability to maintain a reliable and firm comic footing for the film without losing the significance of his message. It's hard to nail down a genre for the movie; it's a dark comedy, a drama, a true crime picture, and a wake-up call. You have moments that feel like a heist flick and moments that feel like a sickening journalistic expose. It's got highs, lows, laughs, groans, and plenty of human emotions, though the most prominent would be disgust and disbelief. The Big Short is advocacy populism as pop-entertainment, and it succeeds ably. It's an economics lesson for the public. At the end of the movie, the closing text informs us about "bespoke tranches," which are investment opportunities that banks are flocking to ($5 billion in 2013 to $20 billion in 2014). It's just another name for CDOs. Unless an informed public demands action from the system, it seems that Wall Street is doomed to repeat its same high-risk mistakes and that same vulnerable public is doomed to clean up the mess.Nate's Grade: A-

While I am always intrigued by a premise like this, I know there will be elements that I will not understand. Surprisingly, I was able to follow this film with ease. "The Big Short" follows groups of people as the statistics of the housing market, leading up to the crash in 2008, are uncovered. The major thing you have to accept in order to enjoy this film, is definitely it's editing style. The shaky camera and quick edits represent the raw feel of the story at hand, and I thought that was fantastic. A terrific screenplay, a stellar cast, and great direction by Adam McKay all make this a film worth watching. It deserves every bit of praise it is getting, even though it's snail pace can become tiring at times. I had a blast watching this movie, as I was able to see all of the behind-the-scenes facts that I did not know about. In the end, if you have patience, this is a terrific film, but that is a necessity to watch this film. "The Big Short" is powerful for what it sets out to say, and nothing more. To me, it is incredibly crafted, but it certainly is not for everyone. Great film!

There's been many films made about the disastrous financial crash of the late 2000s and "The Big Short" may be the best and scathing yet.Adam McKay expertly blends comedy and drama and delivers one of the scariest movies of the year. A tale of human greed, made even scarier by the fact that it was all true, is compelling and quite infuriating. "The Big Short" boasts an impressive cast and they all deliver. Christian Bale and Steve Carell have the showier roles and they revel in them. Brad Pitt is understated yet strong, Gosling is appropriately smarmy. The performance are important to emphasize as without them "The Big Short" would have had a tough time working.The film is definitely politically planted to the left and while that helps with the tone of exasperation it needs, it diminishes the impact the film needs to fully reach all of its audience. The film does sheepishly skirt the fact that our protagonists ultimately benefited from this disaster - and despite the admiration they deserve for spotting a big problem - all they did was make money from it and did not attempt to actively change it. By exposing that raw truth, "The Big Short" could have been scarier.With that said, it is still an incredible film and one of the best of the year. It's a film to be watched by all despite the fact that at the end of the day - it didn't change things one bit.

The Big Short has all the elements of a great film. A great ensemble cast, engrossing story, unique direction, and intriguing characters. Steve Carell gives another sensational performance in this film proving that Foxcatcher was no accident. He brings a funny and emotional performance with an underlying sense of tragedy. Carell shows that he is a force to be reckoned with in cinema, and he should get some serious notoriety come award season. Christian Bale also brings a fantastic performance to the film. His take on an autistic and socially awkward man was great, and he really captures his unique characteristics. Ryan Gosling was the energy in the film, bringing a fun and slick performance and showing once again that he and Carell work perfectly together once again. Brad Pitt gives a sweet performance that I think the audience will be able to relate to the most, even while he didn't have too much screen time. He did a great job. John Magaro and Finn Witrock also gave underrated performances and were a great duo in the film. The script perfectly captures the financial crisis of 2007â"2010 brought on by the build-up of the housing market and credit bubble, and the men who profited off it. While you can't sympathize with many of their actions, especially if you were harmed by these events, you strangely still want them to succeed in their endeavor. Its a very funny yet emotional film, and seeing the events leading up to it is nothing short of fascinating. Adam Mckay is a fantastic director. He brings energy and life to these depressing events and interesting characters, and brings his best film to date. Sometimes the film can be hard to follow and loses focus in some scenes, but overall I really enjoyed the film. The Big Short is a very unique biopic, and thanks to the cast, great script, and Adam Mckays brilliant direction its one of 2015's best films.

THE WHOOPS OF WALL STREET - My Review of THE BIG SHORT (3 1/2 Stars)Writer-director Adam McKay, best known for such zany comedies as ANCHORMAN and STEP BROTHERS, has teamed up with writer Charles Randolph for his shot at something more substantial with THE BIG SHORT, based on the bestseller by Michael Lewis. He mostly succeeds with this funny, confusing, exasperating, artful yet repetitive look at a major financial crisis. Following a group of misfit financial investors who predicted and bet on the fall of the U.S. housing market, the film has a rough start. There's lots of cross-cutting and business lingo thrown at you. If, like me, you just don't understand Wall Street operates, fear not. Once all of the main players are introduced and the predictions of doom have been spelled out, along comes Margot Robbie in a bubble bath to explain it all to you. Breaking the fourth wall, the filmmakers provide a FINANCE FOR DUMMIES moment, the first of many. Stylistically audacious and hilarious to boot, here is where the film finally took off for me. By acknowledging the impenetrability of its subject, I felt able to participate in the story. Although 2011's MARGIN CALL told a similar story, albeit with a much more sobering tone, and WOLF OF WALL STREET turned the investment banking world into one long rave, THE BIG SHORT, a true story, feels unique. Much of that credit goes to editor Hank Corwin, who cuts scenes off mid-sentence and crams in stock footage while juggling a large number of story elements. It's an impressive display from a professional who is no stranger to fast cutting (see NATURAL BORN KILLERS). The cast, particularly Steve Carell and Christian Bale, have a field day with their roles, getting to live out their BOILER ROOM/GLENGARRY GLEN ROSS dreams in this mostly all-male, testosterone-driven fever-pitched battle of subterfuge. While Brad Pitt (in full late 70s Robert Redford mode here) and Ryan Gosling have their moments, Carell and Bale own this film. Playing a short-fused man who feels the hopelessness of taking on the 1%, Carell excels. Imagine if his OFFICE alter-ego, Michael Scott, had lost everything, including his will to live, and gained a terrible hairpiece, and you get his Mark Baum. Bale's Michael Burry exists outside of the main story, yet his presence is essential. Sporting a glass eye and a wardrobe that even The Dude from THE BIG LEBOWSKI would shun, his character plays drums and heavy metal in his basement while figuring out how and when the housing market would crash. Socially awkward yet impressively prescient, Burry becomes our hero of sorts.Here's where my relationship with THE BIG SHORT went from "in love" to "it's complicated". I found myself rooting for men who profited off the backs of people who lost everything when they defaulted on their loans. Yes, one of the main characters offers up this sobering news, but it makes the entire experience of watching this film feel a little icky. Still, I love seeing a filmmaker use his blockbuster capital to stretch. McKay still has a little of that populist huckster in him, that need to entertain, and with a film ultimately as depressing as this one ends up being, that's not such a terrible thing.

I find it interesting that despite how catastrophic the global recession of 2008 was, few movies of quality have centered on the topic. It's probably to do with how confusing the inner workings of Wall Street are to the average person. Even if said workings are all utter bullshit. (See: The Wolf of Wall Street.) This is probably why The Big Short is framed partially as a heist movie with plenty of celebrity cameos to explain exactly what the hell is going on. Big Short is about three different teams of Wall Street investors who notice that the sub-prime mortgage market is headed toward imminent collapse and then decide to do the unthinkable - bet against that market (and therefore the American economy) by shorting their stock and get rich while everyone else reenacts October 1929. Christian Bale succeeds as an anti-social polymath who notices the trend and makes little room for those less intelligent than he (everyone else) and sees his limited group of comrades dwindle further due to his bold decisions. Ryan Gosling does a little too well as a slimy banker who wishes to profit off other people's misfortune. I personally found Steve Carell the true hero of the film both as an actor and character. He is a complete misanthrope who hates the system he is a part of, but at the same time he is a crusader who is deeply wounded by the narcissistic and damaging actions his fellow investors are inflicting on the world economy, despite all of the warning signs. He is a man of lovely contradictions and Carell has fun conveying them. The film is 15 to 20 minutes too long and many of the details are hard to keep track of at times. The dialogue is excellent, and the film goes to great lengths to make the material more enjoyable, such as when characters break the fourth wall and speak directly into the camera. And the message they have is clear - Wall Street screwed you over. And it doesn't care.

Boiler Rooming advanced economics into crazy stupid unlovely shop talk that all filmgoers can understand, pointed morality tale The Big Short qualifies as a drama but the pure lunacy of the story and slick fourth wall-breaking presentation re-package sad true events as one of the sharpest comedies in years. As straight-ahead as the storytelling and stripped-down as the performances are in Spotlight, this film goes the opposite route, making its real-life figures purposely hyper-realistic-just like the ridiculous position they find themselves. Giving the audience gratuitous cheatsheets by having its characters occasionally address the audience directly and, in one example, having alluring actress Margot Robbie explain credit default swaps from a bubble bath, this whipsmart adaptation of Michael Lewis' whipsmart book by the same name winks and nods to the utter madness at hand. In effect, it's not that The Big Short laughs WITH and not AT you, the taxpayers who are still suffering through the fallout of this travesty, it's that the film gets you to laugh at this bubble bursting at all.In this R-rated account of the financial meltdown catalyst of 2008, four denizens of the world of high-finance (Bale, Carell, Ryan Gosling, Brad Pitt) predict the credit and housing bubble collapse of the mid-2000s, and decide to take on the big banks for their greed and lack of foresight. Usually known for capturing Will Ferrell's unique man-child brand of sophomoric clowning, director Adam McCay improbably but brilliantly takes a complicated stock tip and turns it into a savagely funny payout where a marquee ensemble never outshines the unbelievable insanity of the oft-kilter narrative. Bale and Pitt dial it down, making understated performing an art form, while Carell and Gosling go bigger (appropriate to their respective characters). No one showboats, however, for the sake of stealing the spotlight. After all, who could pull focus from the dramatization of a Doomsday Machine? Bottom line: The WTF of Wall Street

The Big Short is scary in the way it makes the audience feel like the housing crisis is something that could very well happen again. The movie is funny, though. Clever editing and amusing performances make for a film that is consistently entertaining. However, as much as McKay tries to get the audience up to speed, there are many terms and phrases not familiar to a casual audience. At a certain point, it becomes impenetrable to grasp all the concepts. Still The Big Short is intelligent filmmaking, and quite thought provoking to boot. Rating: 72

A scathing indictment, a penetrating character study, a political satire, and alternatively a funny yet serious drama, The Big Short is 2015?s most unique film. Based on the book by the same name, the film follows a group of cynical, shrewd, and opportunistic fund managers and Wall Street brokers as they uncover what will soon become the worldwide economic collapse of 07/08. It?s a film that both explores, explains, and revels in the absurdity that lead to the mortgage collapse- condensing a incredibly complicated financial instruments in to a human drama that sifts through all the bravo sierra to the heart of the matter?fraud and greed.Director Adam McKay takes a pretty stark career turn with Big Short, a film with a profoundly serious subject, yet one that McKay manages to find humor in. It?s entertaining, thought-provoking, and yet relentlessly brutal in its pursuit of the truth. The film?s cast is nothing short of exceptional, featuring an ensemble including Christian Bale, Steve Carell, Brad Pitt, and Ryan Gosling. All bring a unique style to the film and inhibit their roles, with an especially impressive showing from both Bale and Carell, enough to garner some award buzz to be sure. The film?s pace is solid, and McKay does a great job interweaving the different subplots to create one over-arching storyline that is secondary to what we all know is about to happen. The film?s moral outrage is palpable, yet justified, a bit preachy, but not singular in its blame. What keeps it anchored is a very intelligent script filled with rich dialogue, smart humor, and attention to detail which refuses to oversimplify what occurred.For some, the film?s eccentricities can be a bit much. It breaks the fourth wall often, which is unsettling at first, and often employs devices such as on-screen definitions, supplied with randomly assorted celebrity break-ins to explain some financial instrument. This contributes to the film?s uniqueness, yet also can result in a disjointed feel from the overall narrative. All in all, McKay?s indulgences as a director pay off more than they don?t, yet there is some inconsistency. The tone is a bit hard to decipher, a comedy in one sense and a drama in the other, yet McKay navigates this by finding dark, cynical, and authentic humor. Simply put, it fits, the cast seems to be thinking??if I didn?t laugh, I?d cry? and we get that.A must see. 4.5/5 Stars

The challenge for me walking into a movie with a script based off a true story is to decide whether or not I have been convinced to a certain level that what I saw was at least truthful to the source material. It makes it even more of a challenge for me to go into a movie blind without having a firm grasp on the source material. What's great about The Big Short, is director Adam McKay acknowledges that I am probably one of many thousands of people who in truth never understood exactly what the housing collapse of 2008 meant to the world. I'd say after just over two hours, not only was I intrigued by the tale and recount of one of the darkest times in American economic history, I was also a bit scared.What we get here are essentially four different approaches to how a few bright and/or hungry minds figured out how to take advantage of the mortgage housing collapse of 2008. We start with Christian Bale's somewhat chaotic character first before moving onto Steve Carell's and Brad Pitt's as we are strung along by the narration of Ryan Gosling. I'm not entirely sure why Gosling was chosen as the narrator, or if one was really needed, but because of it we get some really funny segments when it comes to explaining the complicated concepts of the banks doing what they did.While the acting was pretty solid from this ensemble, unfortunately, it was a little disappointing we didn't get to see more of them interact with each other. The trailer led me to believe this was a group effort to bring to light what the banks were doing, but instead it was more like four individual crusades. You can't really say there were any good guys. There were certainly bad guys.I think what separates this film from being just another ho-hum look at a bad period in American history comes from director McKay. Usually we associate him with comedies like Anchorman. So what we get with The Big Short is actually a movie teetering on the edge of black comedy and drama, though you can certainly feel the disdain of the director for what happened through the dialogue and quick cuts as some real-life stuff is spliced into the film.So while we get four very interesting stories of how these group of bright guys figured out the doom and gloom settling upon us in 2008, the lack of cohesion among our main actors sort of left me wanting a bigger sense of payoff in the end. Not to say it was tough to keep track of, but there was a bit of jumping around. But as I said in the beginning, the attention to detail is staggering and you can't help but feel rotten inside to know something like this was allowed to happen. Surely it can't again. We don't need another one of these well-done movies in the future.

The Big Short: Comes Up Short ***Having read and laughed throughout The Big Short, I was ready to love this film adaptation of Michael Lewis's account of the 2008 Wall Street crash.Lewis has an unmatched talent for exposing prejudice and idiocy in Wall Street and he has been very successfully adapted before in Moneybag (baseball)and The Blind Side (American football). Those tales focussed on one hero and had a clear story arc. I wondered how anyone could take the three heroesof the Big Short and make it work - added to the incredibly complicated machinations of the investment community.On the plus side, you will understand better what the Wall Street idiots did and what they got away with. The comedy director McKay was a good choicebecause he uses every post-modern technique for making it clear. Characters explain to screen, even the gorgeous girl from the Wolf of Wall Street explainsone piece of the puzzle naked in the bath while drinking champagne. It kind of works, but it does not exactly build emotional involvement. On the down side, the 3 plots hang separately - Christian Bale as loner Dr.Burry, Steve Carrell as Baum and his NY team of moral crusaders, and Brad Pitt and his garageboys - all independently work out what was going wrong and decided to short the US mortgage market (deliberately bet against) while everyone else was bettingfor it. Of course, they were right. Now there is progressive complication in all 3 tales, and that's where the film fails to grip. It is emotional overload. Only a few timesin the film did you realise the massive ups and downs the characters were feeling, even after all the clever explanations. I read the book and I could not follow all of it.Someone coming fresh to the film well, good luck.The performances are all good - for once, Bale's weirdness serves him well, Carrell is solid as Baum (with a terrible hairpiece!) and Pitt is outshone by the youngsters in hissegments. The film does not fail to engage and bounce you around for 2 hours and 10 minutes, but never hits the intellectual or emotional heights.It is one of the best films about the financial crisis because it illustrates a Lewis truth - even the losers get lucky sometime. But not that lucky.

There's the guy from New Girl and the cute one from American Horror Story. Look, there goes Amy Pond from Doctor Who and is that Ryan Gosling or Ryan Reynolds? Batman's here too, playing Rain Man and Michael Scott from the Office plays Angry Guy (the only character with a bit more background and nuance). But the real MVP is McKay. This is in some ways a daring movie - it describes the ins and outs of the machinations which led to the 2008 financial melt down with crazy detail - it assumes that the audience should care and understand it. To do that, it sometimes breaks the fourth wall, having actors (occasionally not even characters in the story) address the audience, uses a series of very comprehensible metaphors, and sometimes creates straw man characters and incidents to personify what are really thousands of (mostly) bad actors in the affair. For a business movie, I found it to be much more accurate than most others, although it likes to find easy villains. (For a good analysis, see Michael Grunwald's article in Politico "What The Big Short Gets Wrong."I also must say that many of its heroic characters, while they "win" in the end, take on exactly the sort of reckless financial risks that caused the financial crisis when practiced by the investment banks - the difference being that they happened to bet on the right horse.However, it all holds together marvelously as narrative. The object lesson comes across as an entertaining yarn ultimately about (sort of) little guys taking on the big guys - benefiting only by the fact that they've ignored conventional wisdom and instead done the hard work.

"Everyone, deep in their hearts, is waiting for the end of the world to come."The Big Short is such a refreshing and surprising film because it manages to perfectly balance a difficult subject matter and make it entertaining. It is perhaps one of the most important films made this year reminding us of the worldwide economic breakdown that began in 2007 and left millions of people without their life savings. Many of us don't understand much about economics or how it works, and that is why we have been so eager to forget what happened and continue moving on as if nothing ever happened. This film refreshes our memory and reminds us of what a terrible crime was committed during the housing bubble collapse. The film centers on the few men who recognized the problem early on and took advantage of the situation. The Big Short is a dramatic movie, there is no doubt about it, but it also manages to include some comedic moments by breaking the fourth wall and including pop culture figures to explain some of the more complicated financial terms. It does it in a brilliant way and it's been a while since I've seen a film break the fourth wall as well as this one did. I've seen many documentaries on this subject, but this film manages to explain things better and open our eyes to the dangers we might face again in the future because we've ignored the real problem and seem to be repeating the same mistakes once again. Mckay manages to infuriate and open our eyes while entertaining us at the same time with an engaging film thanks to a witty adapted script which he helped co-write with Charles Randolph.It's not the first time that a film based on a Micheal Lewis novel manages to draw in an audience that doesn't necessarily need to comprehend the subject matter. You could be clueless about baseball, but in Moneyball the story still managed to engage a worldwide audience. The same can be said about this film because the economic terms are explained in a simple way. That is why I believe this is one of the most important films of the year because it allows even those that never seemed interested in economics to understand how it still affects them. It is an eye opening film for those that felt uninterested in trying to understand what happened in 2007. If there is one film that audiences should see this year then this might just be the one (not for its technical or artistic value, but for the importance of its subject matter). The Big Short is Adam McKay's dramatic directorial debut and his background in comedy is what probably helped this film become more accesible. The man who brought us Anchorman, Talladega Nights, Step Brothers, and The Other Guys, now brings us a thought provoking film. He's received two Oscar nominations (directing and writing) for his work here and what an impressive film he has crafted. The film is heavy on dialogue, but the script is so perfectly written that each character in this film becomes memorable. The performances are outstanding which simply proves what a key element writing is for an actor. It was refreshing to see Ryan Gosling back again after his retirement from the big screen for two years. He plays the charismatic character he could easily play in his sleep, but he is still a delight to watch. He delivers a solid role, but out of the four big names it was Steve Carell who stood out. He gets the best dramatic moments and lights up each scene he enters in. Brad Pitt has a smaller role but he makes perfect use of his screen time with an understated performance. Christian Bale is the only actor who received a nomination for his performance in this film and it is well deserved. He plays a socially awkward character and totally sells it. There are films where there are so many big names that no one really gets to shine, but this film manages to make every character memorable thanks to the wonderful script.

Marvelous is the way "The Big Short" is able to make a snoozer of a subject matter turn into high entertainment. If you haven't heard already, it is a black comedy covering the events leading up to the stock market crash of 2008, which is both tragic and fiendishly hard to understand unless you're an economics whiz at the top of your game. To understand the intricacies of its fiscal details is impossible, and while the film is attentive to audiences who likely don't understand what the hell is going on (hilariously using Margot Robbie, Anthony Bourdain, and Selena Gomez to break the fourth wall in an attempt to clearly explain Wall Street terminology), "The Big Short" is less about informatics and more about the dramatic occurrences, the quick-witted exchanges, that took place prior to its climax. It makes for one of the quirkiest and best written films of 2015, its laughs punchy, its more serious pauses littered with the very real sense of collapse the world's economy felt during the crisis. "The Big Short" begins in 2005, where Michael Burry (Christian Bale), an eccentric fund manager, unpredictably stumbles upon inconsistencies in the housing market, where it appears that several mortgages have qualities that suggest they might be fraudulent. Convinced that the market will collapse sometime around the end of 2007, he creates a credit default swap system with big banks that will leave them penniless and him victorious. Unaware that he might actually be right, deals are made without a hint of doubt - regret will come later. Time goes on, and we are introduced to several individuals who become as emphatically aware of the looming financial disaster. One is Mark Baum (Steve Carell), the abrasive manager of FrontPoint Capital; others are Jared Vennett (Ryan Gosling), a confident Deutsche Bank salesman, Charlie Gellar (John Magaro) and Jamie Shipley (Finn Wittrock), up-and-comers who could potentially make a sizable sum if they make all the right moves, and Ben Rickert (Brad Pitt), a Wall Street retiree helping the latter two youths in their risky ambition. While you might not be leaving "The Big Short" with a clear idea as to how the economic system works, you will, regardless, have a better understanding of the trials and tribulations that went down before and after the 2007-2008 financial soap opera, frightened by the ignorance of Wall Street heavyweights of the time yet stupendously entertained by the barbs written by Adam McKay (who also directs) and Charles Randolph - for revolving around such a serious topic, "The Big Short" is an iniquitous comedy of impervious intelligence. Laughs abound when they shouldn't be, and, bruising as they are, are stunning in the way they come effortlessly in a world where comedy shouldn't even accidentally arise. And so I've come to the conclusion that McKay, making his first serious film after years of helming laugh-a-minute Will Ferrell collaborations, can make anything funny - "The Big Short's" combination of genuine rib-tickles and dramatic nuances are what make it such a terrific movie, and its acting, sturdy and revelatory, is predictably excellent from an ensemble of some of cinema's best performers. And I relished the film's aesthetic qualities, which integrates fourth-wall breakings and pop culture asides into the mix like a frenetic MTV oddity. But "The Big Short" remains to be an energetic oddball in the scope of 2015, acting as a highlight in a year full of risk-taking films. So while I may not have always been as distinctly aware of what was necessarily going on during its length (economic lingo is something one can never fully be in touch with), I have no doubt regarding the film's brilliance - this is a unique (pardon the tired adjective) and frenzied take on the biographical movie. It is an exemplary dark comedy.

The Big Short - as I see itDr Manju GuptaThe Big Short is a film about human greed and degradation. It's a film about an eccentric, one eyed hedge fund manager, Michael Burry (Christian Bale) who sees the housing loan bubble burst before anyone else and decides to profit from it by shorting or betting against it. Its about a slickster, Jared Vennett (Ryan Gosling) who hears about these default swaps at a sleazy party and hard sells them for a hefty commission. It's about a seething but righteous Mark Baum (Steve Carell), and his team, who get wind about it through a misplaced phone call, and join in, driven by revenge against the banks. Its about two young and naive fund managers Charlie Geller (John Magaro) and Jamie Shipley (Finn Witrock) who stumble into the information and enter the rat race under the tutelage of a very 'organic' Ben Rickert (Brad Pitt) who has retired from the game in disgust but knows how it's played.What makes this Wall Street film about the 2008 financial meltdown different from others is its unconventional presentation. The director adds colour to the monotony of men in suits by daring to use unconventional ways to explain financial jargon. The narrative is broken by hilarious cameos in which celebrities, playing themselves, define some of the complicated terms like subprime mortgages and collateralised debt obligations. Does all this make you feel bored or stupid? No, I am not asking you, Ryan Gosling posed this question to me as I was watching the film and proceeded to introduce the sultry Margot Robbie who explained the terms while taking a bubble bath. Cheeky yes, but also rare ingenuity!The high profile stars live up to expectations and give excellent performances. Bale's eccentricity seems as real as Carell's smouldering contempt. Gosling's smarmy portrayal of the conscience dead Wall Street shyster is matched with Brad Pitt's brilliantly underplayed avatar as the disillusioned retiree. The naivety of his prot�g� is endearingly genuine too. But its the actors in small roles who shine and make the film what it is. The supercilious banker with his condescending smirk as he puts down the two neophytes, the over helpful assistant who smilingly tolerates Gosling's ill treatment, Carell's well etched team mates, the lady entrusted with credit-rating who has a vision problem, the sleazy home loan mortgage agents, an especially ruthless and repulsive bond trader, the 'law -abiding' tattooed tenant all excel in their craft. There are no small actors here, just small roles.McKay, best known for directing subversive comedies accomplishes a great feat as he pulls out all his tricks, from dizzying hand-held camera moves, peppy dance numbers, quick shots of random people to pole dancers making the movie an exhilarating joy ride. Humour lightens up a dark tale of deceit by having characters break the fourth wall and talk directly to the viewer either to confirm what is happening in the film or to contradict it. But the moral tide running beneath all the laughs is palpable. Five trillion dollars in savings and real-estate value is vaporised as the banks continue to act in an astonishingly ignorant or criminally abusive fashion, leaving millions of Americans jobless and homeless with global repercussions. As the protagonists stifle their disdain for the bond-market creeps, the moral ambiguities cannot be ignored, for they have invested in default swaps, which would pay off only if the market collapses.That it would lead to destruction of such mammoth proportion was probably not foreseeable but the human wreckage is their doing too.A strong contender at the Oscars this year, this film based on a book by the same name can simultaneously outrage and amuse, entertain and educate, infuriate and fascinate and keep the viewer engrossed in a story filled with bond-trade babble. The Big Short, based on true events of an economic catastrophe is devastatingly funny. It will appeal to the average viewer because human greed is not limited to Wall Street and sometimes it's better to laugh than cry.

Based on the true story of how the Global Financial Crisis (GFC) came about from 2005-2008, 'The Big Short' tells the story really well by mixing humour, facts (delivered in an unconventional way by celebrities) and following four tenuously-linked groups who have skin in the game. Vennett (Gosling) introduces us at the start of 2005, via a unique fourth-wall-breaking monologue, placing the players on the field - I'm using this terminology, as most of the film (and Wall Street in general) can be likened to gambling. It may sound boring on the surface - a film about banking and finance - but it does a great job of explaining the terminology in simple terms, whilst not being condescending about it.The groups involved are Burry (Bale), a fund manager and prodigy of sorts, who first sees the housing bubble and notices that the big banks have been over-valuing mortgages (sub-prime). Baum (Carell) and his small company are offered the opportunity to "short" the banks' mortgages by Vennett. Geller (Magaro) & Shipley (Wittrock), two young entrepreneurs, who seek help from their mentor, retired Wall St mogul Rickert (Pitt) also pick up on what' happening and get in on the action. It's great to see the banks gleefully taking their money, being so cocky and greedy, only to have it all blow up in their faces two years later.I think Carell, not Bale, should have been Oscar-nominated for Best Supporting Actor! Baum serves as the film's moral centre and calls everyone on their fraudulent behaviour. The film almost acts as a documentary when it delves down to the individual family level and makes you truly realise how little these large corporations care for other humans. The most bittersweet part is the ending - "and then the crooks went to jail, Congress brought in reform and the fraudulent system was overhauled - just joking! They didn't go to jail, Congress was lobbied so no reform was passed and the big banks were bailed out by the taxpayers" - funny, sad, and true. Really makes you think, but is also a well-made film with excellent acting.

I find it interesting that despite how catastrophic the global recession of 2008 was, few movies of quality have centered on the topic. This is probably why The Big Short is framed partially as a heist movie with plenty of celebrity cameos to explain exactly what the hell is going on. Big Short is about three different teams of Wall Street investors who notice that the sub-prime mortgage market is headed toward imminent collapse and then decide to do the unthinkable - bet against that market (and therefore the American economy) by shorting their stock and get rich while everyone else reenacts October 1929. Christian Bale succeeds as an anti-social polymath who notices the trend and makes little room for those less intelligent than he (everyone else) and sees his limited group of comrades dwindle further due to his bold decisions. Ryan Gosling does a little too well as a slimy banker who wishes to profit off other people's misfortune. I personally found Steve Carell the true hero of the film both as an actor and character. He is a complete misanthrope who hates the system he is a part of, but at the same time he is a crusader who is deeply wounded by the narcissistic and damaging actions his fellow investors are inflicting on the world economy, despite all of the warning signs. He is a man of lovely contradictions and Carell has fun conveying them. The film is 15 to 20 minutes too long and many of the details are hard to keep track of at times. The dialogue is excellent, and the film goes to great lengths to make the material more enjoyable, such as when characters break the fourth wall and speak directly into the camera. And the message they have is clear - Wall Street screwed you over. And it doesn't care.

The Big Short is immediately kind of a weird movie, because it has Christian Bale reprising a role as a Wall Street executive who it totally fucking weird and obsessive about random things, but does a complete 180 from American Psycho by making him a much nicer character. Anyone who's seen both movies will probably pick up this parallel, and it'll make you laugh for a second, but then you'll forget all about it, because this movie is serious business, and the actors are really fucking good. In this film, Patrick Bateman is a brilliant hedge fund manager chilling out in 2005 when he discovers that the housing market is built on a system of fraudulent credit ratings and horribly convoluted wall street bullshit: shitty loans, masturbatory economists, labyrinthine CDO's, etc. Have no idea what I'm talking about? Well, this film is ahead of you and will explain all of this stuff along the way (often using clever visuals, or easy to digest metaphors with famous actors, musicians and economists serving as cameo lecturers). So, Bateman being the hotshot broker he is decides he's going to bet against the (at the time) AAA rated housing market. Everyone thinks he's crazy as fuck, so when he goes to the banks to pitch his idea, they're more than enthusiastic as he puts something like 1.4 billion dollars into the scheme. Well, you can't put this much money into a scheme without somebody noticing, and entrepreneurial believers like Ryan Gosling, Steve Carell, Brad Pitt, and others come climbing out of the woodwork to get in on the action. Bale, once he's made his move jut sits on his ass and waits for the money to roll in, but Carell wants to figure out why this is all happening. His character will take you into the rabbit's hole that is Wall Street fuckery, offering one part Chinatown-esque detective style unraveling storyline, and one part real-life journalist expose on what the fuck exactly happened to cause the 2008 collapse. The film is based on actual events that happened, so this film should almost be required viewing for anyone who lives in North America. "But I just want to watch a stupid movie and not learn anything when I go to the cinema!" Well, shut the fuck up, because this isn't about what you want. There's no sound argument for being willfully ignorant, and this film does a good job of pointing out how harmful such placated indifference can end up being. This is a two hour film that not only manages to entertain you and make you laugh, but it also informs you on how and why you may have gotten fucked. The acting is good, the music is solid, the camera work is kind of creative, the dialogue is fast and exciting, the editing is punchy. It's very possible that this movie will end up disappearing into shadows for being too intellectual, or for being about finance, and that would be a terrible shame.TL;DR - 8/10 As I said earlier, this film should be required viewing. This is the best performance I've seen out of Ryan Gosling, it might be the best performance I've seen out of Steve Carell. The subject matter is important; and I mean it's important for all of us to understand, and be upset about it. Do yourself a favor and go and watch this movie, at the very least you'll have a good time, but you might also learn something while you're at it.

In retrospect it is amazing how unprepared the world was for the collapse of the sub-prime mortgage market which was the basis for billions of dollars of managed funds and bank investments . This movie deals with those few who bothered to do their research and realised, some by luck and some by judgement, that the house of cards was going to fall. It is a fascinating insight into greed, fraud and basic stupidity and what makes it all even more staggering is the fact that it all happened. It is not a film that will suit all as it requires a basic understanding of the workings of financial markets, and that is not everyone's idea of entertainment. But it is exceedingly well done and has a terrific cast led by the always brilliant Christian Bale and the sometimes adequate Steve Carell who is at his best in this. I loved it.

This review is part of a class assignment (sorry to people who want to read actual reviews). Over the holidays I had the opportunity to see The Big Short, which I watched for the second time last Friday. I was pleased to see that the movie held up throughout repeated viewings, a feat which I attribute to the spectacular acting, sardonic humor, and the profound subject matter. The Big Short focuses on Wall Street investors who predict the financial crash of 2008 by doing what no one else at the time was doing- paying attention. The film follows the Wall Street misfits as they discover the corrupt and fraudulent systems upon which the American economy is based. What separates The Big Short from other financial films is that the creators go through enormous pains to make sure that the audience understands the transactions taking place, rather than merely having to accept it as Wall Street mumbo-jumbo. By cleverly utilizing celebrities and simple analogies, the directors reduce abstruse Wall Street jargon into understandable terms and concepts for lay people. (For example, Margot Robbie clarifies that "sub-prime" just means "shit" as she soaks in a bubble bath, sipping champagne.) This feature of the movie is exactly what makes The Big Short so important- yes, it's entertainment (honestly, it's hilarious), but it is also a worthy educational tool that explains the largest financial crisis in modern history to a broad public audience.

Excellent performances all around, particularly Steve Carell, who stands out as the movie's conscience. Wryly humorous, but ultimately heartbreaking in its depiction of how Wall Street and the government through greed, malfeasance, and stupidity, bilked millions of innocents of their homes and retirement savings.

Before ever stepping into a theater to watch this film, I knew going in that Adam McKay was in the directors chair. Two thoughts ran through my head. One, what was the director of both Anchorman movies, Talladega Nights, The Other Guys, and Step Brothers doing, directing a movie up for multiple Oscars? Not to say that those films are bad in any way, because I love each of them, especially the underrated buddy cop movie, The Other Guys. But really? Adam McKay? And the second thought was; Is this going to actually be funny? Well much to my surprise, a lot of it actually was. And I was extremely pleasantly surprised to see that Mr. McKay was able to transition well from the likes of Will Ferrell schlock, to a possible best picture win. The movie centers around a couple or more main characters during the 2008 crash of the housing market.. Michael Burry (Christian Bale) is a hedge fund manager that was able to predict the impending crisis years before it actually happens. He makes some questionable investments, in preparation for the collapse, which is much to everyone's dismay. Trader, Jared Vennet (Ryan Gosling), gets wind of Michael's investments and starts to figure out the same thing. Soon enough others do as well, and from there on out the story unfolds as a different cast of characters prepare for the crisis. Now , just to give everyone some background on myself, I am a nine-teen year old college student. I have absolutely no interest in the housing market, mortgage rates, CDO's, or banking period. With that being said, I believe the filmmakers understood this fact wholeheartedly. They were able to take a subject, and a story, that was extremely complicated, and make it entertaining and enjoyable. In fact, I think that is the best aspect of this movie. Much like The Wolf of Wall Street, this film is dirty with fourth wall jokes, celebrity cameos, and an overall joking tone. This does seem odd and unconventional, given the subject matter. But they are able to make it work brilliantly. For a movie about the housing market, there was not a second when I found myself bored. I was engaged the whole time, and honestly was starting to feel a little pissed because of what had actually happened. Given the films credit, I believe that was their intention. For a movie that is slated at over two hours, the pacing was very well, and thanks to Adam McKay's brilliant direction, I found myself laughing for most of the runtime. The casting in this movie was simply fantastic as well. Christian Bale is basically a more buff version of Jessie Eisenberg in The Social Network. He is a genius, but has no idea what to say or how to say them. Think Sheldon from The Big Bang Theory, only not that bad. I found that very odd, especially for Christian Bale. Although at this point in his career, he could probably play a woman, and convince me all the same. Ryan Gosling reprises his role, almost, from Crazy, Stupid, Love. He is smooth, and sophisticated, and just the right amount of jerk you want on wall street. I could talk all day about the cast, however the biggest win here is certainly Steve Carell. As a comedian, he is one of the funniest I have ever had the pleasure of watching. As a serious actor, he also hits a home-run. I have been saying for a long time that I believe comedians can be the best actors, and time and time again they prove it to me.  Overall, this is most definitely one of the years best films, and I would say the best film of Adam McKay's career thus far. The subject is extremely convoluted, but it doesn't matter thanks to the brilliant writing, and the awesome direction. The cast all give great performances, my favorite coming from Steve Carell, which make for an extremely enjoyable film. I would not recommend this for everyone, but most will find great entertainment out of it. I would give this movie 4/5 stars. Definitely worth the price of admission!

As straight-ahead as the storytelling and stripped-down as the performances are in Spotlight, this film goes the opposite route, making its real-life figures purposely hyper-realistic-just like the ridiculous position they find themselves. Giving the audience gratuitous cheatsheets by having its characters occasionally address the audience directly and, in one example, having alluring actress Margot Robbie explain credit default swaps from a bubble bath, this whipsmart adaptation of Michael Lewis' whipsmart book by the same name winks and nods to the utter madness at hand. In effect, it's not that The Big Short laughs WITH and not AT you, the taxpayers who are still suffering through the fallout of this travesty, it's that the film gets you to laugh at this bubble bursting at all.In this R-rated account of the financial meltdown catalyst of 2008, four denizens of the world of high-finance (Bale, Carell, Ryan Gosling, Brad Pitt) predict the credit and housing bubble collapse of the mid-2000s, and decide to take on the big banks for their greed and lack of foresight. Usually known for capturing Will Ferrell's unique man-child brand of sophomoric clowning, director Adam McCay improbably but brilliantly takes a complicated stock tip and turns it into a savagely funny payout where a marquee ensemble never outshines the unbelievable insanity of the oft-kilter narrative. Bale and Pitt dial it down, making understated performing an art form, while Carell and Gosling go bigger (appropriate to their respective characters). No one showboats, however, for the sake of stealing the spotlight. After all, who could pull focus from the dramatization of a Doomsday Machine? Bottom line: The WTF of Wall Street

Surprisingly enough, a filmmaker like Adam McKay, known more for his work with the "Anchorman" films, "Talladega Nights", "Step Brothers", and other ridiculous romps in comedy, is the perfect compliment to infuse a little bit of life in this assumed to be stale topic. Adapted from the also titled 2010 New York Times Best Selling novel, "The Big Short" poses as an expose' going behind the curtain of the crisis. Through the perspective of a group of individuals (portrayed by the all star cast) who anticipated the downfall of our economy due to this rotten financial structure, we get some shocking insight as to how this all came to be, the effect it truly had on the world, and what happened when this group decided to do the unprecidented thing in betting AGAINST the American economy for profit when damn near everybody was under the delusion it was rock solid. . . I must at this point applaud the efforts from all parties of the film responsible for their execution in what truly was a circus tight rope balancing act. This film had to walk a really fine line between the drama and comedy genres it was blending. Filmmaker McKay and the performances of his team had to be engaging, witty, and often times comical enough to catch the attention of audiences despite the technical and arguably boring material they had to work with. They had to do this for entertainment value, but still needed to acknowledge while paying respect to the overall situation and the consequences that came from it. This crisis ruined lives. People lost jobs, people lost homes, people went hungry, and many people even died during this dire time. . . In the grand scheme of things, this was in no angle of looking at it EVER considered a laughing matter. Yet, "The Big Short" performs the balancing act with grace as the audience has an easy time transitioning between the funny moments as well as the sad. Christian Bale and Steve Carrell lead the charge with truly memorable performances as filmmaker McKay's change of pace film comes off as much educational as it does entertaining. Adam McKay is not exactly the kind of name you associate with a prestige picture that's building serious Oscar heat. McKay is best known as the director and co-writer of Will Ferrell's best movies, from Anchorman and its sequel to Talladega Nights and the underrated 2010 buddy cop movie, The Other Guys. If you stuck through the closing credits for Guys, you were treated to an animated education lesson on the size of Wall street's greed and accountability in regards to the 2008 financial crisis. It was impassioned, angry, and an interesting note to end an otherwise goofy comedy. The Big Short is based upon Michael Lewis' (Moneyball) best-selling book and it's a disaster movie where the biggest disaster is the world economy. The movie McKay co-adapted and directed is bristling with intelligence, indignation, and a clear purpose. He wants to make you very angry, and by the end if you're not, you haven't been paying enough attention.In the wake of the financial collapse in 2008, the fallout was so tremendous that many people felt nobody could have seen this coming. There were a few and they made out like bandits while trying to warn others about the impending doom. In the early 2000s, Michael Burry (Christian Bale) is a hedgefund manager who sees warning signs that the housing market is a bubble ready to burst. He sees the toxicity of the majority sub-prime mortgages wrapped together and sold as a seemingly safe security, a CDO (collateralized debt obligation). His bosses think he's mad and they're furious when they discover Burry has gone from bank to bank making big bets against the housing market. The banks are eager to take what they believe to be easy money from a sucker. How could the housing market burst? Other Wall Street investors take notice of Burry, notably Jared Vennett (Ryan Gosling) who pitches the plan to "short" the housing market. Nobody takes him seriously except Mark Baum (Steve Carell) and his small team who works for Goldman Sachs. Baum is curious how something so large could go unnoticed, so he and his team fly to Florida and Vegas to investigate the realities of the market and what they find does not match the rosy cheerleading from Wall Street. A pair of wannabe traders (Finn Witrock, John Magaro) stumbles across Burry's analysis and try to make their own bets, except they need a bigger name to make the trades. They reach out to an ex-Wall Street trader (Brad Pitt) who agrees to shepherd them on this quixotic quest. Are these men righteous defenders of fraud or just people trying to get their own cut of the pie?The brilliance of The Big Short lies in its accessibility and the virulent passion that McKay has for the subject matter. The movie is structured like a heist and an underdog story, suckering in the audience to root for the upstarts trying to fleece the big banks and profit off their greed and stupidity. For the first 90 minutes or so, the film comes across like a caper and we follow our group of misfits as they fight against the conventional wisdom that the housing market could never topple. These guys see the signs and the risks that others could not or would not see, especially since the flow of money was rich and the good times could be shared, which lead to collusion from the very same agencies designed to regulate and enforce the financial laws. For those 90 minutes the movie flies by on its sense of whimsy and are-we-getting-away-with-this good fortune, putting our band of misfits in position to win big on the losses of the ignorant and fraudulent. And then, in one swift move, it all comes down and you're reminded, rather indignantly by Pitt's character, that what they are benefiting from is the meltdown of the U.S. housing market and by extension the American economy. What once felt like a celebratory caper now starts to feel queasy, and it's in the last act that The Big Short reminds you just how awful the events of the 2008 financial crisis were and how these guys did nothing more than benefit from mass misery. These are not heroes, though Mark Baum is given plenty of moral grandstanding moments that present him as the closest thing we have in the picture. These were a bunch of guys who got rich betting on a lot of other people's bad bets, bets that almost destroyed the world's economic systems. The concluding half hour feels like a sudden stop after a sugar rush, where you're left to question your decision-making but also come to terms with the reality of what seemed like a fun time. McKay lures his audience in with the guise of a heist/underdog story, appealing and accessible avenues of cinema, and then serves the cod hard medicine in the concluding moments.McKay is admirably trying to educate and advocate while he entertains, but he truly wants the audience to understand why they should be sharpening their pitchforks. At several points, characters will break the fourth wall and talk directly into the camera, admitting that certain events didn't happen exactly as we saw, or occasionally they'll remind us that what we watched was exactly how it happened. It's a measure that isn't overplayed and helps juice the spirits of the movie, becoming something of a confidant in the schemes with the onscreen participants. When things gets a little hard to understand with the mountain of Wall Street lingo, McKay will cut to celebrity cameos to help explain the more arcane instruments of the financial system. Margot Robbie luxuriates in a bubble bath and explains sub-prime mortgages, Anthony Bourdain explains CDOs, and Selena Gomez, in a rather cogent analogy, explains synthetic CDOs as an endless chain of side bets being made off one hand of blackjack. The movie goes pretty fast and a viewer might experience information overload, but McKay knows when to slow things down and provide a well-timed assist, so that his learned audience will see the true extent of the corruption and greed rampant in how Wall Street handled its business.Of the three storylines, I found Mark Baum and his team easily the most interesting and I think McKay and co-screenwriter Charles Randolph (The Interpreter) agreed, which is why he's the biggest part of the movie. Burry gets things started but he recedes into the background after the first act, and that's where Baum and his financial team step into the spotlight to further explore how unstable the housing market just might be. I think this is Carell's best dramatic performance to date (I wasn't wowed by Foxcatcher). He's playing perhaps one of the angriest people seen on screen but that's because he has a moral center and the bad business practices, let alone the sociopathic greed of his "peers," constantly enrage him. He's something like a flabbergasted crusading journalist who keeps shaking his head in stupefying revulsion at just how deep this whole thing goes. Having Baum as our entry into the moral morass of Wall Street allows the audience to feel a sense of ethical superiority, and then like Pitt's character, it can all go away with one perfectly articulated retort. There's a moment where Baum is lambasting a mortgage ratings officer (Melissa Leo, her only scene too) after she admits that if they don't rate bad mortgages as good, the banks will just go to their competitor, and then she accuses Baum of being a hypocrite. His reason for the office visit is not that his outrage at the fraud but the fact that this fraud is holding up his winnings. He's not the crusader he may wish to be. Bale (American Hustle) and Gosling (Only God Forgives) are perfectly cast and provide strong supporting work in small doses spread throughout. There is a bevy of familiar faces (Marisa Tomei, Rafe Spall, Max Greenfield, Karen Gillan) appearing in small moments as if everybody in Hollywood wanted to get in on McKay's party.There is one annoying misstep in the movie and it occurs about halfway and it's made to stretch out the stakes in a haphazard manner. The Big Short is a disaster movie where the audience knows exactly when the disaster is coming, and yet there's a section in the middle where the characters are all left in doubt whether their big bets will pay off because of the ratings fraud. Burry is threatened with losing his job. It's silly because we know the economy is going to crash in 2008, but the movie throws out a weak obstacle that, hey, maybe it won't crash. It reminds me of the Hinderberg movie from the 1970s. There were several moments where it looked like that zeppelin full of hydrogen was going to go up in fames... except students of history know that moment is fated in New Jersey, so all the close calls were foolish fake-outs for a major event that was well anticipated. We all know the economy is going down so there's no need for the manufactured doubts.McKay and company want to wake up a fairly apathetic general public about the crimes and negligence of the Wall Street robber barons that risked the world's economy and then managed to skip out on the tab. The tones can juggle wildly, and I'd credit McKay's background in comedy for his ability to maintain a reliable and firm comic footing for the film without losing the significance of his message. It's hard to nail down a genre for the movie; it's a dark comedy, a drama, a true crime picture, and a wake-up call. You have moments that feel like a heist flick and moments that feel like a sickening journalistic expose. It's got highs, lows, laughs, groans, and plenty of human emotions, though the most prominent would be disgust and disbelief. The Big Short is advocacy populism as pop-entertainment, and it succeeds ably. It's an economics lesson for the public. At the end of the movie, the closing text informs us about "bespoke tranches," which are investment opportunities that banks are flocking to ($5 billion in 2013 to $20 billion in 2014). It's just another name for CDOs. Unless an informed public demands action from the system, it seems that Wall Street is doomed to repeat its same high-risk mistakes and that same vulnerable public is doomed to clean up the mess.Nate's Grade: A-

A movie well worth all the awards buzz.Obviously the movie is well-cast. Anyone can see that. But the success of a movie isn't just based on the people on the screen but largely on the ones behind it. Director Adam McKay somehow made economics interesting and upbeat and personal. He made it actually accessible to an average American. Use of pop culture stars like Margot Robbie and Selena Gomez to explain Wall Street mumbo jumbo in layman's terms was pure genius.The humor is sharp and quick and bitter. When you laugh, you laugh at a joke made at the expense of six million American people. You laugh at a joke about the worst recession in American history since the stock market crash nearly a century ago. You laugh because you can't help it, and you know that you're laughing at a terrible thing. That kind of humor saves the movie. It's what keeps viewers on their toes.Ryan Gosling's smart and quick narration traded an outrageous, highly improbable movie about an event for an outrageous, highly improbable movie about a true event that everyone needs to get pissed about - and he did that without being a good guy. The stars of the movie are usually called the "protagonists," but this is a story of all villains. The people we root for are the ones who bet against the American economy. They're the ones who saw the bankers' fraud and called their bullshit and profited from it. How can we cheer for them? How can we not when the only alternative is to cheer for the bankers who pulled the wool over the eyes of the entire nation - the entire world?For me, the most relatable character is Steve Carrell's portrayal of Mark Baum. He's a cynical, paranoid idealist. He hates the banks. He bets against the American economy and hopes it doesn't work. He understands better than anyone that if they win, if the banks lose, he personally will be rich, and America will be ruined. And when they do win, when the real estate bubble does pop, when the system does reveal itself as totally broken, he's devastated. And by the end of this movie, so was I.But don't take my word for it. Go see it for yourself. Go be amazed and devastated at once. GO see it now before the bankers get the wool out again.
